articles.headline: U.S. to Recognize 1,300 Marriages Disputed by Utah
articles.snippet: The decision furthered President Obama’s self-described evolution on same-sex marriage rights as his administration appeared closer to confronting a state over its refusal to recognize such rights.
articles.abstract: The decision furthered President Obama’s self-described evolution on same-sex marriage rights as his administration appeared closer to confronting a state over its refusal to recognize such rights.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Friday made the latest contribution to a fast-moving legal battle over same-sex marriage rights as the Justice Department said that the federal government would recognize as lawful the marriages of some 1,300 same-sex couples in Utah even though the state government is largely refusing to do so.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage and Jack Healy

articles.headline: Jobs Data Gives Hope for Benefits Extension
articles.snippet: The Senate will consider legislation to revive expired benefits for 1.3 million out-of-work Americans on Monday, but it appears gridlock will continue.
articles.abstract: The Senate will consider legislation to revive expired benefits for 1.3 million out-of-work Americans on Monday, but it appears gridlock will continue.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The surprisingly weak December jobs report might have strengthened Democrats’ hand in the current fight over emergency jobless benefits for the long-term unemployed even as it weakened the party in the larger midterm election battle.
articles.byline: By Annie Lowrey and Jonathan Weisman

articles.headline: Justices Take Case on Free TV Streaming
articles.snippet: Broadcasters contend Aereo’s service violates copyright laws. The company says it is not covered by the relevant provisions of those laws.
articles.abstract: Broadcasters contend Aereo’s service violates copyright laws. The company says it is not covered by the relevant provisions of those laws.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday agreed to resolve a dispute between television broadcasters and Aereo, an Internet start-up that the networks say threatens the economic viability of their businesses.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak and Bill Carter

articles.headline: The Next Data Privacy Battle May Be Waged Inside Your Car
articles.snippet: As cars increasingly come equipped with Internet connections, GPS and data recorders, concerns about what is being tracked and who has access to it.
articles.abstract: As cars increasingly come equipped with Internet connections, GPS and data recorders, concerns about what is being tracked and who has access to it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cars are becoming smarter than ever, with global positioning systems, Internet connections, data recorders and high-definition cameras. Drivers can barely make a left turn, put on their seatbelts or push 80 miles an hour without their actions somehow, somewhere being tracked or recorded.

articles.headline: Federal Consumer Agency Ponders Its Next Crusades
articles.snippet: Several advocacy groups say they hope to see the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau make significant process on overdraft fees, debt collection and mandatory-arbitration clauses in contracts.
articles.abstract: Several advocacy groups say they hope to see the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau make significant process on overdraft fees, debt collection and mandatory-arbitration clauses in contracts.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, which has already overcome considerable political resistance, has managed to pack some punches in the last few months on behalf of the purchasing public it represents.

articles.headline: To Regain Trust, Target Must Do More, Crisis Experts Say
articles.snippet: The recent revisions of the extent of the hacking at Target raise serious questions about security.
articles.abstract: The recent revisions of the extent of the hacking at Target raise serious questions about security.
articles.lead_paragraph: With clients over the years like Michael R. Milken (securities fraud), Dominique Strauss-Kahn (rape allegations), Jack Abramoff (bribery) and the Sizzler restaurant chain (salmonella), Marina Ein is well versed in the art and science of crisis public relations.

articles.headline: Wall St. Shock: Take a Day Off, Even a Sunday
articles.snippet: After a review, Bank of America Merrill Lynch said its lowest-level employees should try to take four weekend days off each month.
articles.abstract: After a review, Bank of America Merrill Lynch said its lowest-level employees should try to take four weekend days off each month.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the ambitious college graduates who flock to Wall Street, working into the wee hours or even pulling all-nighters is an unwritten expectation of the job. Spending both Saturdays and Sundays at the office is the norm.
articles.byline: By William Alden and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: Ariel Sharon, Israeli Hawk Who Sought Peace on His Terms, Dies at 85
articles.snippet: Mr. Sharon was both vilified and admired for his belief that Jews must assert and defend their collective needs without embarrassment or fear of censure.
articles.abstract: Mr. Sharon was both vilified and admired for his belief that Jews must assert and defend their collective needs without embarrassment or fear of censure.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ariel Sharon, one of the most influential figures in Israel’s history, a military commander and political leader who at the height of his power redrew the country’s electoral map, only to suffer a severe stroke from which he never recovered, died on Saturday in a hospital near Tel Aviv. He was 85.

articles.headline: Bailout Risk, Far Beyond the Banks
articles.snippet: In the too-big-to-fail parade, what about a closer look at the asset management firms that oversee trillions of investor dollars?
articles.abstract: In the too-big-to-fail parade, what about a closer look at the asset management firms that oversee trillions of investor dollars?
articles.lead_paragraph: Everyone knows that the largest of our nation’s banks would be destined for a taxpayer bailout if they ran into trouble anytime soon. But which nonbank financial institutions — say, asset management companies offering hedge funds or mutual funds — might also pose too-big-to-fail risks because of their size and interconnections?

articles.headline: Eminent Domain: A Long Shot Against Blight
articles.snippet: The mayor of Richmond, Calif., is pushing a novel use of eminent domain to prevent foreclosures. Financial firms are very, very unhappy.
articles.abstract: The mayor of Richmond, Calif., is pushing a novel use of eminent domain to prevent foreclosures. Financial firms are very, very unhappy.
articles.lead_paragraph: You can’t fight city hall, the saying goes. But Gayle McLaughlin, the mayor of Richmond, Calif., a city of 100,000 souls, would tell you that fighting Wall Street is harder. Even for city hall.

articles.headline: In Scandal’s Wake, McKinsey Seeks Culture Shift
articles.snippet: Touched by scandal, a firm that has long relied on a culture of trust has laid down some tougher rules to follow.
articles.abstract: Touched by scandal, a firm that has long relied on a culture of trust has laid down some tougher rules to follow.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dominic Barton is 51 years old, 6 feet 4 and silver-haired, yet he has the countenance of a choirboy. Born in Uganda, he is the son of a missionary and a nurse, both Canadians. But it could be said that the society to which he really belongs is that of McKinsey & Company.

articles.headline: Defying Japan, Rancher Saves Fukushima’s Radioactive Cows
articles.snippet: Angered by what he considers Japan’s efforts to sweep away the inconvenient truths of a nuclear disaster, a rancher returns to the no-man’s land near the devastated plant.
articles.abstract: Angered by what he considers Japan’s efforts to sweep away the inconvenient truths of a nuclear disaster, a rancher returns to the no-man’s land near the devastated plant.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAMIE, Japan — His may be one of the world’s more quixotic protests.

articles.headline: Banks Say No to Marijuana Money, Legal or Not
articles.snippet: Banks across the country are reluctant to provide services to marijuana businesses, fearing that federal regulators and law enforcement authorities might punish them.
articles.abstract: Banks across the country are reluctant to provide services to marijuana businesses, fearing that federal regulators and law enforcement authorities might punish them.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — In his second-floor office above a hair salon in north Seattle, Ryan Kunkel is seated on a couch placing $1,000 bricks of cash — dozens of them — in a rumpled brown paper bag. When he finishes, he stashes the money in the trunk of his BMW and sets off on an adrenalized drive downtown, darting through traffic and nervously checking to see if anyone is following him.

articles.headline: A National Strategy Funds State Political Monopolies
articles.snippet: In some states, campaign cash from sophisticated donor networks has helped accelerate or arrest the natural drift toward one party or the other, defying national election trends and voter registration advantages.
articles.abstract: In some states, campaign cash from sophisticated donor networks has helped accelerate or arrest the natural drift toward one party or the other, defying national election trends and voter registration advantages.
articles.lead_paragraph: By his third year as chairman of the Alabama Republican organization, Mike Hubbard believed his party had just about everything it needed to win control of the State Legislature.

articles.headline: Negotiators Put Final Touches on Iran Accord
articles.snippet: Iran and a group of six world powers completed a deal on Sunday that will temporarily freeze much of Tehran’s nuclear program in exchange for limited relief from Western economic sanctions.
articles.abstract: Iran and a group of six world powers completed a deal on Sunday that will temporarily freeze much of Tehran’s nuclear program in exchange for limited relief from Western economic sanctions.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Iran and a group of six world powers completed a deal on Sunday that will temporarily freeze much of Tehran’s nuclear program starting next Monday, Jan. 20, in exchange for limited relief from Western economic sanctions.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: More Movies at Sundance Are Sidestepping the Big Screen
articles.snippet: Movies at the festival may take in even less at the domestic box office as digital-leaning distributors become the most active buyers.
articles.abstract: Movies at the festival may take in even less at the domestic box office as digital-leaning distributors become the most active buyers.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — What will be the difference between this year’s Sundance and the Sundance of 2006, when independent film was last riding high?
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Michael Cieply

articles.headline: Where Free Speech Collides With Abortion Rights
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court will hear challenges on Wednesday to a 2007 law limiting anti-abortion campaigners from communicating with women entering clinics, which they contend infringes on their rights.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court will hear challenges on Wednesday to a 2007 law limiting anti-abortion campaigners from communicating with women entering clinics, which they contend infringes on their rights.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — A couple of mornings a week, Eleanor McCullen stakes out a spot outside the Planned Parenthood clinic here and tries to persuade women on their way in to think twice before having an abortion.

articles.headline: Saving Relics, Afghans Defy the Taliban
articles.snippet: At the National Museum of Afghanistan, the most important objects smashed by the Taliban have been reassembled, and looted treasures have also been returned.
articles.abstract: At the National Museum of Afghanistan, the most important objects smashed by the Taliban have been reassembled, and looted treasures have also been returned.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Every piece of antiquity that is restored to the halls of the bombed, pillaged and now rebuilt National Museum of Afghanistan sends a message of defiance and resilience.

articles.headline: Buffing a Battered City’s Image
articles.snippet: City leaders in Detroit say they hope visitors will see a revival underway in a city lately known for bankruptcy.
articles.abstract: City leaders in Detroit say they hope visitors will see a revival underway in a city lately known for bankruptcy.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Ever since Detroit filed for bankruptcy six months ago, political and business leaders here have insisted that the city’s long-awaited comeback has already begun.

articles.headline: Roger Ailes’s Permanent Pushback Campaign
articles.snippet: Gabriel Sherman’s portrayal of the Fox News operation in his new book is hardly shocking, but it is not a pretty picture, and Mr. Ailes must know that.
articles.abstract: Gabriel Sherman’s portrayal of the Fox News operation in his new book is hardly shocking, but it is not a pretty picture, and Mr. Ailes must know that.
articles.lead_paragraph: Roger Ailes, the chairman of Fox News Channel, has little left to accomplish in a remarkable television career. He has made billions for his owners, created an entirely new genre of TV and, in doing so, he has changed the way politics is conducted. His business legacy is secure.

articles.headline: Cost of Cool in India? An iPhone
articles.snippet: To draw young buyers and increase its market share in India, Apple has offered promotions like monthly payments and trade-ins.
articles.abstract: To draw young buyers and increase its market share in India, Apple has offered promotions like monthly payments and trade-ins.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANGALORE, India — After deliberating for months, Abhilash Sathyendra, a 25-year-old equity adviser in Mysore, India, bought his first Apple phone. He paid 9,000 rupees, or $150, upfront for a black iPhone 4s and swiped his credit card for the remainder, six no-interest monthly payments of $62.50.

articles.headline: Twinned Cities Now Following Different Paths
articles.snippet: Duluth, Minn., and Superior, Wis., are so close physically and culturally that they are known as the Twin Ports. But much began to change when Minnesota government went all Democratic and Wisconsin all Republican.
articles.abstract: Duluth, Minn., and Superior, Wis., are so close physically and culturally that they are known as the Twin Ports. But much began to change when Minnesota government went all Democratic and Wisconsin all Republican.
articles.lead_paragraph: DULUTH, Minn. — The soaring Blatnik Bridge spans a modest body of water but a political gulf.

articles.headline: Need Cash? Own a Bentley? Take a Pawn Ticket
articles.snippet: An increasing number of pawn businesses are catering to the wealthy, offering fast liquidity in exchange for high-end luxury items like Rolex watches and Bentley automobiles.
articles.abstract: An increasing number of pawn businesses are catering to the wealthy, offering fast liquidity in exchange for high-end luxury items like Rolex watches and Bentley automobiles.
articles.lead_paragraph: Walk into the Suttons & Robertsons showroom on the East Side of Manhattan and it looks like any high-end retailer or auction house: necklaces glittering with diamonds, sapphires and emeralds fill the display cases, and sterling silver knives, forks and spoons sit on a wooden table fit for a monarch. In the private room in back are bigger, shinier versions of the jewels out front.

articles.headline: My Old Osaka Home: Suntory of Japan to Buy Maker of Jim Beam
articles.snippet: A privately held giant known for producing Japan’s first whiskey has agreed to acquire the maker of Jim Beam and Maker’s Mark bourbons, and Teacher’s and Laphroaig Scotch whiskies.
articles.abstract: A privately held giant known for producing Japan’s first whiskey has agreed to acquire the maker of Jim Beam and Maker’s Mark bourbons, and Teacher’s and Laphroaig Scotch whiskies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Few spirits are as American as bourbon. But the maker of some of whiskey’s most iconic brands, including Jim Beam and Maker’s Mark, will soon belong to an acquisitive Japanese beverage maker.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and David Gelles
